Mariupol, Ukraine: A model city of 'new Russia'
subhead: Since 2015, photographer Gabriele Micalizzi has been documenting the Donbas region from the Russian side of the front line, an area where Moscow enforces very strict access conditions for journalists. In November, he secured permission to enter Donetsk Oblast, a region of occupied Ukraine, and traveled to Mariupol, a city destroyed by Russian forces in 2022, which has since been colonized and rebuilt in record time.
byline: By Gabriele Micalizzi  (Mariupol (Ukraine), photographer) and Benjamin Quénelle

title: Three women stabbed in the Paris metro, a suspect has been arrested
Trump orders strikes on 'terrorists' in Nigeria, bolstering cooperation with Abuja
In Belarus, the shadow political prisoners
subhead: Beyond the roughly 1,000 political prisoners who have been officially identified, hundreds more languish in prison without being recorded. The regime of Alexander Lukashenko has done everything it can to keep them hidden and ensure they are forgotten.

title: Semiconductors: ASML, the tech giant at the center of the US-China conflict in the race for AI
subhead: 'Microchips: The Oil of the 21st Century' (4/5). ASML's ultra-advanced lithography machines are used to etch the most cutting-edge microprocessors, which are crucial for artificial intelligence – a major strategic issue.

title: Where have all the New York City children gone?
subhead: 'My Christmas under Trump' (5/5). Journalist Georgia Husson settled in New York right in the middle of the holiday season preparations. Today, she recounts her impossible quest to find a gift for her young goddaughter. It would be easier if it were for a dog.
byline: By Georgia Husson (New York, special correspondent)

title: In the home of Zara, at the heart of fashion photography
subhead: In just four years, Marta Ortega Pérez, head of the Spanish group Inditex, has transformed her foundation in A Coruña, Galicia, into a venue showcasing the greats of fashion photography. Following retrospectives dedicated to Peter Lindbergh, Irving Penn and Helmut Newton, American photographer Annie Leibovitz has been exhibiting her work in this former industrial building in the port since the end of November.

Why more young people are turning to religion
subhead: Many researchers have observed a resurgence of religious commitment among young people in France, often accompanied by a certain rigorism. This renewed spiritual quest is linked both to the anxieties of our era and, at times, a search for identity.

title: Semiconductors: Nvidia at the heart of the new Pacific battle
subhead: 'Microchips: The Oil of the 21st Century' (1/5):  Whether it's AI, electronics or defense, the 'silicon economy' drives the entire industrial and service sectors. It is at the heart of a fierce battle between global powers, with China seeking to free itself from dependence on US technologies.
byline: By Harold Thibault (Beijing (China) correspondent) and Arnaud Leparmentier (San Francisco (United States) correspondent)

title: 'Drone overflights are testing our defense capabilities,' says French military intelligence and security chief
subhead: Despite heightened vigilance from his teams, General Aymeric Bonnemaison, director of the French military security agency, admits that it remains difficult to identify the culprits of suspicious incidents. Since September, there has been a sharp increase in drone overflights of military installations.
byline: Interview by Chloé Hoorman and Elise Vincent
